items.title: [pyclustering.cluster.xmeans] MNDL incorrect formula

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Tasks related to found bugs

items.body:
**Introduction**
MNDL formula has a mistake in line with the paper `Improving X-Means Clustering with MNDL - M.Shahbaba, S.Beheshti`.

Incorrect part in the code:
```python
scores = sigma_sqrt * (2 * K)**0.5 * ((2 * K)**0.5 + betta) / N + W - sigma_sqrt + Ks + 2 * alpha**0.5 * sigma_sqrt / N
```

**Description**
Scores should be calculated correctly.

items.title: process() stops without explanation when medoid initial indices are out of range

labels.name: Duplication
labels.description: Tasks related to already existed problems

items.body:
If I use 
from pyclustering.cluster.kmedoids import kmedoids
samples = [some list of arrays, the list has a length of 8]
initial_medoids = [1, 5, 8] (randomly chosen)
kmedoids_instance = kmedoids(samples, initial_medoids)
kmedoids_instance.process() will stop the script and make forget all of the variables

There is no explanation that the script stops because of wrongly chosen initial_medoids indices.

kmedoids_instance.process() will create a nullpointer and stop. No explanation was given that the index 8 is out of range. Instead, all of the variables in memory are lost after this and the script cannot be tested any further without a full restart, and it took me some time to find out the small mistake. Of course, index 7 is the highest possible index if you have 8 samples and I know that. First, I was new to this clustering method and I did not even know that the indices of the medoids are indexes for the samples and not indexes inside the sample arrays, and thus I did not know that I had to align the max index with the length of the samples list, and second, it is not explained clearly that the length of the initial_medoids determine the final number of clusters, at least when I believe this post: 

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56978613/how-to-use-kmedoids-from-pyclustering-with-set-number-of-clusters

Quote: "It is true you can control the number of cluster, which correspond to the length of initial_medoids.
The documentation is not clear about this. The get__clusters function "Returns list of medoids of allocated clusters represented by indexes from the input data". so, this function does not return the cluster labels. It returns the index of rows in your original (input) data."

items.title: GA: add a get_labels() or predict() method
items.body:
Currently the GA class hast the `get_clusters()` method which returns a list of `K` sub-lists (where `K` is the number of clusters) each containing the indexes of the elements that correspond to that cluster. Usually one wants the labels of each element that associate it with a given cluster, somethign like this:

    labels = np.zeros(data.shape[0])
    for i, clust in enumerate(ga_instance.get_clusters()):
        labels[clust] = i
    labels = labels.astype(int)

The clustering methods in `scikit-learn` all have a unified `labels_` method that returns this.

Bug has been revealed during code review of KD-tree. Search rule has been used only for right branch.

```
        req_node = None
```

items.title: [C/C++ pyclustering] Forbid to use `cluster_data`

labels.name: Proposal
labels.description: Tasks that have been proposed by users

labels.name: Refactoring
labels.description: Tasks related to code refactoring

items.body:
**Introduction**
Current interface may confuse because `cluster_data` might be used instead of concrete type (such as `dbscan_data`, `fcm_data`, etc.). As a result segmentation fault occurs. The `cluster_data` shouldn't be accepted by algorithms to avoid this situation, concrete implementation should be used instead. If there is no concrete implementation than alias must be created.

**Description**

- [x] Update algorithm interface in order to use concrete type of data instead of `cluster_data`.
- [x] Update unit-tests.
- [x] Look for possibilities to forbid allocation of `cluster_data`, for example, to make it pure abstract class with partial implementation.

**Links**
There is an issue that indicates problem of current interface: #576 .

items.title: [pyclustering.cluster.center_initializer] possible bug in random_center_initializer __create_center() method

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Tasks related to found bugs

items.body:
First, thank you for a fabulous clustering library. 

I was having issues with the random_center_initializer: all the initial clusters seemed to be close to the first few data items.  

I think I found a bug in the `random_center_initializer` `__create_center()` method.

In **center_initializer.py**, see line 92:
```
   85     def __create_center(self, return_index):
   ...
   92         random_index_point = random.randint(0, len(self.__data[0]))
   93         if random_index_point not in self.__available_indexes:
   94             random_index_point = self.__available_indexes.pop()
   95         else:
   96             self.__available_indexes.remove(random_index_point)
   97 
   98         if return_index:
   99             return random_index_point
  100         return self.__data[random_index_point]
  101
```

in **line 92**, `self.__data[0]` refers to the first list element, which will only be as long as there are columns in the input data. 

I think you want line 92 to be: 
```
   92         random_index_point = random.randint(0, len(self.__data))
```

Now, `len()` returns the number of items in `__data`.

I have changed that locally and now `random_center_initializer.initialize()` returns a more uniformly distributed list of starting cluster centers. 

Cheers, David

items.title: Extend data type for sequential algorithm (*sas)

labels.name: Question
labels.description: Tasks that are questions from users

items.body:
Is there a way to use these algorithms with non-vectorial data structures such as strings or graphs? This should be straightforward if the updating rule could take a distance matrix as input or compute it in place by defining a suitable distance measure, as already defined in kmedoid.
Am I wrong or actually something similar is not yet implemented  for this algorithms?

There is recommendation to downgrade it.

items.title: [pyclustering.container.cftree] Farthest nodes calculation bug

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Tasks related to found bugs

items.body:
**Introduction**
There is bug in line with code review of CF-Tree:
```python
    def get_farthest_successors(self, type_measurement):
        farthest_node1 = None
        farthest_node2 = None
        farthest_distance = 0.0
        
        for i in range(0, len(self.successors)):
            candidate1 = self.successors[i]
            
            for j in range(i + 1, len(self.successors)):
                candidate2 = self.successors[j]
                candidate_distance = candidate1.get_distance(candidate2, type_measurement)
                
                if candidate_distance > farthest_distance:
                    farthest_distance = candidate_distance
                    farthest_node1 = candidate1
                    farthest_node2 = candidate2
        
                return [farthest_node1, farthest_node2]  # <------ return result after the first iteration.
```

When the issue is fixed, one of the BIRCH tests is failed:

**Introduction**
There is request to obtain Gower distance:

> I am studying for a Data Science Fellowship through my work and as part of this I have various projects to produce to show my understanding of each concept.  The first one is around clustering: I was trying to cluster a large dataset of mixed variable types (categorical, continuous and ordinal) and after much searching discovered that the appropriate methodology was to apply a Gower Distance matrix to the K-medoids functionality.  Your package provided the k-medoids functionality and accepts a distance matrix as an input which is awesome.  I am working in python and it appears that most of the stuff I need is implemented in R but not in python.

labels.name: Enhancement
labels.description: Tasks related to enhancement and development

items.body:
**Introduction**
Algorithm for random sampling is required for CURE to work with big data.

**Description**
Implementation should be based on the article: 'Random Sampling with a Reservoir - JEFFREY SCOTT VITTER':
```
@article{Vitter:1985:RSR:3147.3165,
 author = {Vitter, Jeffrey S.},
 title = {Random Sampling with a Reservoir},
 journal = {ACM Trans. Math. Softw.},
 issue_date = {March 1985},
 volume = {11},
 number = {1},
 month = mar,
 year = {1985},
 issn = {0098-3500},
 pages = {37--57},
 numpages = {21},
 url = {http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/3147.3165},
 doi = {10.1145/3147.3165},
 acmid = {3165},
 publisher = {ACM},
 address = {New York, NY, USA},
} 
```

The implementation should be standalone and provide services to clients like CURE. Currently, CURE algorithm is only one client of this random samplier therefore it should provide all services that are required for CURE.

items.title: SKlearn Wrapper

labels.name: Question
labels.description: Tasks that are questions from users

items.body:
Hi,

in order to use GridSearch, Pipeline, etc. from SKLearn I tried to write a wrapper to be consistent with the SKLearn API.
Here is an example for KMeans that uses Jaccrd distance instead of Euclidean:
```
class KMeansWrapper(BaseEstimator, ClusterMixin):

    def __init__(self, n_clusters, tolerance=0.001, max_iter=200):
        self.n_clusters = n_clusters
        self.tolerance = tolerance
        self.metric = self.__jaccard
        self.max_iter = max_iter
        self.wrapped_instance = None
        self.labels_ = None
        self.centers_ = None

    def fit_predict(self, x, y=None):
        x = check_array(x, accept_sparse='csr')
        self.wrapped_instance = kmeans(data=x,
                                       initial_centers=kmeans_plusplus_initializer(x, self.n_clusters),
                                       tolerance=self.tolerance,
                                       metric=self.metric,
                                       itermax=self.max_iter)
        self.wrapped_instance.process()
        self.labels_ = self.wrapped_instance.get_clusters()
        self.centers_ = self.wrapped_instance.get_centers()

        return self.labels_

    def fit(self, x):
        x = check_array(x, accept_sparse='csr')
        self.wrapped_instance = kmeans(data=x,
                                       initial_centers=kmeans_plusplus_initializer(x, self.n_clusters),
                                       tolerance=self.tolerance,
                                       metric=self.metric,
                                       itermax=self.max_iter)
        self.wrapped_instance.process()

        self.labels_ = self.wrapped_instance.get_clusters()
        self.centers_ = self.wrapped_instance.get_centers()

        return self

    @staticmethod
    def __jaccard(p1, p2):
        return (np.logical_and(p1, p2).sum() / float(np.logical_or(p1, p2).sum())).T
```

Am I abusing something here?

items.title: Use random restarts to give consistent results

labels.name: Proposal
labels.description: Tasks that have been proposed by users

items.body:
Currently only 1 run of kmeans is done inside the improve parameters method, and this often leads to local minima even on the simplest examples (below is the demo program ran twice). There should be an option for random reinitializations of kmeans, selecting the one yielding the lowest total distance inside this function to give consistent output at the tradeoff of increased runtime.

![ccore_on](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5508542/60545431-0e230580-9ce9-11e9-8d3f-76a3b16f2802.png)
![ccore_off](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5508542/60545435-0fecc900-9ce9-11e9-9bdb-b337c6e10362.png)

items.title: [pyclustering.cluster.kmedoids]: add stop condition 'max_iterations'

labels.name: Proposal
labels.description: Tasks that have been proposed by users

items.body: The kmedoids algorithm in practice seems to converge pretty quickly, but since the centroid can potentially jump around a big distance as it moves from point to point and not a mean distance (like with kmeans) the stop condition of `tolerance` might not catch when a centroid is jumping between one point and the other, right? Perhaps a `max_iterations` argument might be better than tolerance? I would think that kmeans and kmedians might also benefit from this secondary catch.

items.title: [ccore.clst.silhouette] CCORE Silhouette implementation

labels.name: Enhancement
labels.description: Tasks related to enhancement and development

labels.name: Good First Issue
labels.description: Tasks that can be easily done by contributors

items.body:
**Introduction**
Silhouette uses C/C++ implementation of K-Means, but also performs analysis of obtained results where Python implementation is used. In the case of big data and search range, a lot of resources are spent to transfer results from and to CCORE and it increases the complexity of the algorithm by

**O(n) * 2 * (kmax - kmin);**

Therefore pure C/C++ implementation of the algorithm is required to avoid useless data passing (reduce complexity).

**Description**
Following tasks should be done in the scope of the issue:
- [x] Silhouette and interface to it should be implemented using C/C++ (namespace ccore.clst, class silhouette).
- [x] Unit and integration tests for the implementation are required.
